section.title: Sizing Number of HTTP Threads to Connection Pool
section.para: When running under load in production and against a database, you'll want to size the number of HTTP threads concurrently processing web requests based on the number of connections available in your database connection pool so you don't have too many requests waiting to grab a connection from the pool and timing out. The specific ratio of HTTP threads to database connection pool size will depend on your application, but a good starting point is 1 to 1.

example.title: Database Connection Pool (config/database.yml)
example.para: production: adapter: mysql database: my_database host: my_host username: my_username password: my_password encoding: utf8 pool: 100This example sets the database connection pool size to 100.

section.title: Setting Max Number of HTTP Threads
section.para: If using the torquebox-server gem, you can pass the --max-threads parameter to set the maximum number of HTTP threads. $ torquebox-server run --max-threads=25
If not using the torquebox-server gem, you can control the maximum number of HTTP threads by setting a system property.

table.title: Number of HTTP Threads System Property

row.entry: The maximum number of threads to use for the default HTTP connector. If you've changed the connector's name from http in standalone.xml then substitute http for the new connector name in the property key. The default value is inherited from AS7 and is 512 * the number of CPUs.

example.title: Number of HTTP Threads ($JBOSS_HOME/standalone/configuration/standalone.xml)
example.para: <extensions> ... </extensions> <system-properties> <property name='org.torquebox.web.http.maxThreads' value='100'/> </system-properties> This example sets the maximum of HTTP threads to 100.
